posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
So I’m looking at cameras for an Orange Pi setup

First am I correct in assuming that for April Tag detection I’m looking for Global Shutter BW/Mono 720p 100 fps or higher?  Better on fps first resolution second?  I know the OV9281 is top notch on this front.

Second when choosing a color camera for object detection what shutter/resolution/fps should I be be looking for?  Should I emphasize res or fps or the other way around?  We’re looking for Arducam models in particular.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
I’ve just gotten a global shutter 100 fps color camera for both AprilTag and object detection.

IIRC, it uses an OV9782 sensor, and it’s worked great for us.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Should I emphasize fps over res and if so minimum res 720pish?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Higher FPS is especially important for AprilTag cameras, so the tags aren’t distorted during periods of high motion. I guess it would also help for object detection for the the same reason.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Any concerns with PhotonVision setting the mode to Black and White?  Simple toggle switch or bit of a pain

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
I haven’t had an issue with leaving it as a colour picture for AprilTag detection. At most I just turn down the brightness a bit. Auto exposure usually does well enough.

There isn’t a switch in PhotonVision to turn off colour, and I don’t think there’s a saturation slider.

You could use Linux UVC webcam tools to do it, if you really want.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Multi Camera Support.  I think I’d like to max out the USB ports with 4.  Any limitations.  If so would more RAM fix, etc.?

I think I’m going with the Orange Pi 5 Plus so would 16 GB work or less or more?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Limitation would be processing power. And the USB bus bandwidth.

I haven’t seen anyone try plugging in 4 cameras into an Orange Pi. Many mini PCs don’t even have suitable USB bandwidth for that.

RAM isn’t really a limiting factor. 8GB should be plenty, 4GB would probably be fine too.

Here’s a document with some testing done with an Orange Pi.

Introduction	2 Materials	3 Software Setup	5 General Troubleshooting	6 Camera Tests	7 OV9281	7 AR0144	8 OV9281 + AR0144	8 Conclusion	9   Last updated: 2/3/2023 Introduction This paper details how to set up an Orange Pi 5 (Opi5) with Photonvision for...

There are other mini PCs that can do 4 cameras. If you want to use an Orange Pi, you’ll likely need 2 to run 4 cameras.

link_counts.title: Orange Pi Guide For Photonvision 2023 - Google Docs

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Another thing to think about is, you’ll want to rename each of your cameras to have a different device name, to make things easier when setting up pipelines.

Use this utility to change the name of each camera to something like “blah_A”, “blah_B”, etc. https://docs.arducam.com/UVC-Camera/Serial-Number-Tool-Guide/

Note that this utility only works with Arducam cameras.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
So the Orange Pi5 can handle 2 streams relatively well with some fiddling with the settings so it would seem?

If so I’m sure the Pi5 Plus can do better.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Also any good recommends for a VRM .  The Pi5 Plus takes 5V, 4A.  I saw the doc showed one for 5V, 3A

posts.name: Anish M
posts.cooked: for our robot, orange pi 5 is handling 3 streams at once and we haven’t had many problems with it

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: So a 5 Plus could conceivably bump that up to 4?  Of course testing is required

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: You’d wanna buy multiple anyway, for replacements, and concurrent testing.

posts.name: Carlos Gross Jones
posts.cooked:
viggy96:

Higher FPS is especially important for AprilTag cameras, so the tags aren’t distorted during periods of high motion.

Note that, for reducing motion blur, you actually want a short integration time, which is mostly separate from framerate. A global shutter also eliminates tearing, which can look similar to motion blur. What a high framerate does for you is to reduce latency.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.custom_user_title: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: So integration in terms of robot integration or area of the curve integration.  Not sure what you’re referring too, but am eager to learn more.

posts.name: Carlos Gross Jones
posts.cooked: The camera’s integration time. An image sensor is basically an array of photodiodes, which convert photons to electrons, each with an attached capacitor. To take an image, you turn on all the pixels, then let them sit for a while; any incoming photons get turned into electrons, which are stored in the capacitor. This is the integration. After a while, you read out all the pixels by measuring the voltage on each capacitor. The greater number of photons that hit that pixel, the greater the voltage will be. If you integrate for longer, you capture more photons, but also, if there’s motion, you’ll get motion blur. This is basically the same as the shutter speed on an SLR film camera. Typical integration times for these sort of small cheap cameras are from a few microseconds to a few milliseconds.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.custom_user_title: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: So nothing tunable then as a single setting?

I would just use a 5A or 10A breaker on a PDP / PDH or the REV mini power module, and then send it though a Polulu buck converter to regulate voltage to 5v. The classic VRM is limited to 2A so I would avoid it.
